section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need the Number Cards showing numerals one through five.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Baby Animals with Their Families, we stopped to count animal family members.
In this activity, we’ll count the animal babies we see in a picture, say how many babies we count, then point to a Number Card with the same number on it.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Counting Show the chimpanzee family on pages 2–3. Point to and count each chimpanzee aloud. Then say, Three is the last number I said, so that is the number of chimpanzees. I need to find the Number Card showing the number 3. Here it is!
Set Up Place the five Number Cards on the table, face up.

Play Hold up an Activity Card and ask a child to count the number of animal babies on it. Guide the child to say the number of animals (“I count two elephants.”), and then point to the Number Card with the matching numeral.
Repeat Ask another child to count the baby animals in a different order and confirm that the total is the same. Continue the game until every child has had a turn.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When counting, remember that the last number said is the total number in all. Even when we count objects in a different order, if the last number said is the same, the total number of objects in all is also the same.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start with three Numeral Cards and three matching Activity Cards. Count the number of babies out loud, and ask, How many in all? Point to the babies in a different order and count again.

Invite children to show the number of babies on one card using the fingers on one hand, and the number of babies on another card using the fingers on their other hand. Then ask, How many babies in all?

Review the names of the animals featured on the Activity Cards and number names for one through five before playing. You can also suggest children use number names from their home language to count the animal babies.
To support the fine motor needs of the children in each group, consider having children use a pointer to indicate the Activity Cards or Numeral Cards as they participate.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Animal Babies with Their Families, we used our ask and answer questions Mind Builder skill to talk about baby animals.
Now we are going to ask and answer questions as we look at other animal babies.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Play Show each activity card to the group. Call on volunteers to ask questions about the baby animal in the picture. After each question, ask: Does anyone think they can answer that question? If children have difficulty answering a question (for example, How many wings does a baby swan have?), prompt them to use their imagination to answer it. If the technology is available, make a list of unanswered questions and research the answers on the Internet as a group.
Repeat Continue the activity until at least one question has been asked and answered for each Activity Card.

Talk About Questions and Answers How did the questions and answers you asked connect to what you learned in Animal Babies with Their Families? Do you have any other questions about the baby animals in the book or on the Activity Cards? Make a concept web of any extra questions, and look the answers up later if technology allows.
Help children think of questions by pointing to one element of each Activity Card and asking, What do you see here? Do you wonder anything about this part of the picture?
Invite children to ask a question about an animal they already know about, without looking at pictures for reference. Invite other children to try to answer the question.

Review the words “question” and “answer”, as well as the names of the animals in the pictures. Have children say these words in their home language. During the activity, suggest children say the name of the animals in their home language, then encourage them to say it in English.
Consider helping children with their questions or answers by saying the first word or two of a sentence that may be giving them difficulty.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need several Connecting Cubes or other concrete manipulatives.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Animal Babies with Their Families, we counted animals and added up the numbers to tell how many animals were in a family.

In this activity, we’ll count the animals in a family and then send some of the animals away to “find food” for their babies. Then we’ll say how many animals remain. You will pretend to be the animals from the book!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Play Have five children stand in a circle and pretend to be whales. Ask, How many whales in all? Ask two whales to swim away to “find food.” Then ask, How many whales are left?
Repeat Play the activity several times, using different animal types, and different numbers of animals that stay and go away. Give children an opportunity to participate in multiple word problems.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Subtraction is the same as take away. When we take away objects, the total number gets smaller because there are now fewer objects. When the animals left to find food, there were less animals left in the circle, so we were subtracting.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Let children work with concrete manipulatives such as Connecting Cubes during the activity. Help children by writing each number you say or using a similiar grouping of items for each number.
Ask, If three whales need to stay behind to take care of the babies, how many whales can leave to find food? Have children use their fingers to find the answer.

Review and write each numeral from one to five, as well as the names of each animal baby, before beginning the activity. If necessary, encourage children to say the number in both their home language and English when playing.

Encourage children to move as the animals when acting out the word problem. If they are whales who are swimming away, they should move their flippers to swim. Monkeys can swing away on branches and birds can fly through the trees.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need ten Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Chicks Say, Pio Pio, we saw the mother hen taking care of her chicks.

In this activity, I will be the mother hen and you will bring me chicks to take care of. I’ll call out a number of chicks, and you will count that number of chicks and bring them to me to keep safe. You will each get ten chicks.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Play Have children sit in a row, and give each child ten Connecting Cubes as “chicks.” Sit across from the group as the “mother hen.” Say, I can give shelter to three chicks! Guide children to each count out three “chicks” and bring them to you.
Repeat Continue to call out numbers of chicks until the “mother hen” has given all chicks shelter. Play again with different numbers of chicks.

Talk About Same and Different Assign two children to be “mother hens” and repeat the activity, encouraging each “mother hen” to say a same or different number of chicks. After each turn ask the children whether the number of chicks each mother hen asked for is the same or different. Use one-to-one matching if children need help.

Start the activity with five “chicks” per child. Help children by writing the number of chicks, showing Number Cards or Magnetic Numbers, or holding up your fingers to indicate the amount of chicks they need.
After each round, ask, How many chicks do you have left? Ask children to describe their thinking.
Review each number from one to 10, as well as the words shelter and fewer before starting the activity. Suggest children say the number in both their home language and English as “mother hens.”
Have children use tweezers to slide each “chick” to the “mother hen,” or write the number of chicks they want on paper as “mother hens.”
